contentrichtext.text: {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} [[File:Makibi Enomiya-Lasalle (1898-1990).jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.1|Father Hugo Enomiya-Lassalle]] {{Zen Buddhism}} {{Western Buddhism}} '''Aiun-ken Hugo Makibi Enomiya-Lassalle''' (born 11 November 1898 in Gut Externbrock near [[Nieheim]], [[Province of Westphalia|Westphalia]]; died 7 July 1990 in [[Münster]], [[North Rhine-Westphalia|Westphalia]]) was a German [[Society of Jesus|Jesuit]] priest and one of the foremost teachers to embrace both Roman Catholic [[Christianity]] and [[Zen]] [[Buddhism]]. Enomiya-Lassalle joined the [[Society of Jesus]] on 25 April 1919. At the end of the usual Jesuit spiritual and academic training he was ordained [[Catholic priest|priest]] on 28 August 1927. He travelled to Japan as a [[Catholic missionary|missionary]] in 1929 and became interested in that country's [[Buddhism|Buddhist]] practices. In 1940, he became the vicar of [[Hiroshima]], and on 6 August 1945 he was critically wounded by the nuclear blast in that city. Shortly thereafter, he returned to Germany. In September 1946, he had an audience with [[Pope]] [[Pius XII]], in which he revealed his plan to build in Hiroshima a [[cathedral]] dedicated to the idea of world peace. Designed by Japanese architect [[Togo Murano]], construction on the cathedral began in 1950 and on 6 August 1954, the [[Memorial Cathedral for World Peace]] （[[:ja:世界平和記念聖堂|ja]]）was dedicated [http://hiroshima.catholic.jp/~pcaph/cathedral/?page_id=2]. In 1956, Enomiya-Lassalle began studying Zen with [[Harada Daiun Sogaku]]. In 1958, he published ''Zen: A Way to Enlightenment'', but the [[Holy See]] ordered him not to continue publishing on the subject. [[File:Hiroshima World Peace Memorial Cathedral.jpg|thumb|left|upright=0.9|Memorial Cathedral for World Peace, at Naka-ku Hiroshima Japan, design by Togo Murano in 1954]] Following Harada's death in 1961, Enomiya-Lassalle became an apprentice of one of Harada's students, [[Yamada Koun]]. Yamada was enthusiastic about the possibilities of Zen as a Christian practice, believing that "''Zen would become an important stream in the Catholic Church one day''".<ref>[http://terebess.hu/english/sharf.html Terebess Asia Online]</ref> With Enomiya-Lassalle's active assistance, he attracted a number of Catholic priests and nuns as students. In the late 1960s, Enomiya-Lasalle was certified as a teacher in Yamada's [[Sanbo Kyodan]] sect and given the title ''[[Rōshi|roshi]]'' ([[Zen master]]), while professing his continued belief in Christianity. After 1968, Enomiya-Lassalle spent much of his time in Europe leading Zen retreats and encouraging Zen practice among Christians. Then around 1983 he began to draw heavily from [[Jean Gebser]], [[Sri Aurobindo]] and [[Pierre Teilhard de Chardin]] to point to a new cultural paradigm based on [[integral consciousness]].[http://www.jean-gebser-gesellschaft.ch/TransDok/Jean%20Gebser%20and%20Zen.pdf] Lassalle published ''The Practice of Zen Meditation'', (1987, [[HarperCollins|Thorsons]]). ==See also== *[[Heinrich Dumoulin]] ==References== <references/> {{Authority control|VIAF=110718436}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Enomiya-Lassalle, Hugo | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH = 11 November 1898 | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = 1990 | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Enomiya-Lassalle, Hugo}} [[Category:1898 births]] [[Category:1990 deaths]] [[Category:People from Höxter (district)]] [[Category:People from the Province of Westphalia]] [[Category:German Jesuits]] [[Category:Japanese Jesuits]] [[Category:German Zen Buddhists]] [[Category:Converts to Buddhism]] [[Category:Buddhism and Christianity]] [[Category:Naturalized citizens of Japan]] {{zen-stub}} {{Christian-bio-stub}}
